citation.article-title: Streptomyces caviscabies sp. nov., from deep-pitted lesions in potatoes in Québec, Canada

p.s: Description of Streptomyces caviscabies sp. nov.
Streptomyces caviscabies (ca.vi.sca'bies. L. adj. cavus, hollow; L. n. scabies, mange; caviscabies, referring to the ability of the organism to cause deep-pitted scab of potatoes)
The eight deep-pitted-scab-inducing strains are characterized by a gold mycelium on YME medium and a white mass of spores borne in flexuous chains.
The cylindrical, smooth spores are 0.87 to 1.08 by 0.5 to 0.63 μm (Fig. 2).
The cell walls contain LL-diaminopimelic acid, and the DNA G+C content is 71 mol%.
The strains do not produce melanin.
All strains grow on proline or methionine as a sole nitrogen source.
They utilize raffinose as a sole carbon source.
All strains grow in the presence of 4% NaCl, 0.1% phenol, 10 IU of penicillin per ml, 10 μg of thallous acetate per ml, and 20 μg of streptomycin sulfate per ml.
Strain EF-87 (= ATCC 51928) is the type strain of S. caviscabies.
